title: GitHub Actions Workflows Quiz
description: Master GitHub Actions workflows, YAML syntax, marketplace actions, and modern CI/CD automation

questions.title: Workflow Trigger Events
questions.description: Which trigger event allows you to manually run a GitHub Actions workflow from the Actions tab?
questions.explanation: The `workflow_dispatch` event allows manual workflow execution from the GitHub Actions UI. It can accept input parameters for customization.
questions.hint: The keyword includes 'dispatch' for sending workflows on demand.

questions.title: GitHub-Hosted Runners
questions.description: What is the default runner operating system if no `runs-on` is specified in a GitHub Actions workflow?
options: There is no default, it must be specified
questions.explanation: GitHub Actions requires an explicit `runs-on` specification. There is no default runner. Common choices are ubuntu-latest, windows-latest, or macos-latest.
questions.hint: GitHub enforces explicit runner selection for clarity.

questions.title: Secrets Management
questions.description: How do you access a repository secret named `API_KEY` in a GitHub Actions workflow?
questions.explanation: Repository secrets are accessed via the `secrets` context: `${{ secrets.SECRET_NAME }}`. Secrets are encrypted and masked in logs.
questions.hint: Secrets have their own dedicated context namespace.

questions.title: Matrix Strategy Basics
questions.description: What does a matrix strategy in GitHub Actions allow you to do?
options: Run jobs in a specific order
Run the same job with different configurations in parallel
questions.explanation: Matrix strategies run the same job multiple times in parallel with different variable combinations (e.g., testing across Node 14, 16, 18).
questions.hint: Think of testing across multiple versions or environments simultaneously.

questions.title: Popular Marketplace Action
questions.description: Which action is required as the first step in most GitHub Actions workflows to access repository code?
questions.explanation: The `actions/checkout` action clones your repository to the runner, giving subsequent steps access to your code. It's almost always the first step.
questions.hint: This action 'checks out' your code to the runner.

questions.title: Action Versioning Best Practice
questions.description: What is the recommended way to version actions in production workflows?
options: Pin to a specific commit SHA
questions.explanation: Pinning to a commit SHA (e.g., `actions/checkout@a12b3c4`) ensures immutability and prevents breaking changes. For convenience, major version tags (e.g., @v4) are also acceptable.
questions.hint: The most immutable versioning approach uses the git commit hash.

questions.title: Reusable Workflows
questions.description: How do you call a reusable workflow from another workflow?
questions.explanation: Reusable workflows are called using `uses:` with the full path including repository, file path, and ref: `owner/repo/.github/workflows/file.yml@ref`.
questions.hint: The syntax is similar to calling marketplace actions, but points to a workflow file.

questions.title: Conditional Job Execution
questions.description: Which expression would run a job only on push to the main branch?
questions.explanation: The `github.ref` context contains the fully qualified ref (e.g., 'refs/heads/main' for branches, 'refs/tags/v1.0' for tags). Always use the full ref path.
questions.hint: GitHub uses fully qualified references like 'refs/heads/' for branches.

questions.title: Concurrency Control
questions.description: What does the `concurrency` key in a workflow do?
options: Limits how many jobs run simultaneously
Controls how many runners can execute the workflow
Prevents multiple workflow runs from executing concurrently for the same concurrency group
Sets the maximum number of matrix jobs
questions.explanation: The `concurrency` key groups workflow runs. When a new run starts, previous runs in the same group can be canceled (with `cancel-in-progress: true`) or queued.
questions.hint: It prevents overlapping deployments or concurrent runs of the same workflow.

questions.title: Environment Protection Rules
questions.description: What can you configure with GitHub environment protection rules?
options: Required reviewers and wait timers before deployment
The operating system for the runner
questions.explanation: Environment protection rules allow you to require manual approvals from specific reviewers and add wait timers before deploying to environments like production.
questions.hint: Protection rules add gates before deploying to sensitive environments.

questions.title: Docker Container Jobs
questions.description: How do you run a job in a custom Docker container?
questions.explanation: The `container:` key specifies a Docker image for the job. Steps run inside this container instead of directly on the runner.
questions.hint: The keyword is the same as what Docker uses to describe images.

questions.title: Dependency Caching
questions.description: Which action is commonly used to cache dependencies and speed up workflows?
questions.explanation: The `actions/cache` action stores and restores dependencies (like npm packages, pip packages) between workflow runs to reduce build time.
questions.hint: The action name directly describes its function.

questions.title: Artifact Management
questions.description: What is the retention period for artifacts uploaded with `actions/upload-artifact`?
questions.explanation: By default, artifacts are retained for 90 days, but this can be configured at the repository level. You can also specify retention per artifact using the `retention-days` parameter.
questions.hint: The default is longer than a month but less than a year.

questions.title: Workflow Debugging
questions.description: How do you enable debug logging for a workflow run?
options: Add debug: true to the workflow YAML
Set repository secret ACTIONS_STEP_DEBUG to true
questions.explanation: Setting the `ACTIONS_STEP_DEBUG` repository secret to `true` enables debug logging, showing additional diagnostic information for troubleshooting workflow issues.
questions.hint: Debug mode is enabled via a special repository secret.

questions.title: Composite Actions
questions.description: What is the main advantage of composite actions over JavaScript or Docker actions?
options: They can combine multiple steps into a single reusable action without requiring code
They have access to more GitHub contexts
They can run on all platforms
questions.explanation: Composite actions let you bundle multiple workflow steps into a single action using YAML, without writing JavaScript or building Docker images. They're simpler to create and maintain.
questions.hint: Composite actions are defined purely in YAML, combining existing steps.
